stream_context.summary: Kaze worked on building out the final platforming paths for Course 15, designing and modeling assets like flying cars, a gramophone staircase, and a retro-futuristic CRT monitor. He also discussed his philosophy on hub worlds, plans for a commercial Steam release, and debugged a hardware crash caused by excessive level complexity.

development_findings.summary: Kaze is methodically building out the final sections of Course 15, adding platforming elements like flying cars and staircases one piece at a time.
development_findings.quote: I have to do one thing at a time. I can't just teleport it all in.

development_findings.summary: Kaze's design philosophy prioritizes maintaining the core Mario 64 moveset, preferring to build platforming challenges rather than introducing vehicle sections that alter gameplay significantly.
development_findings.quote: I don't like to take the base Mario 64 movement away from the player too much.

development_findings.summary: Performance is a key concern in a complex area of Course 15. New assets must be low-polygon to avoid lag on N64 hardware.
development_findings.quote: The problem we have in this area is that this area is already very complex. And it's going to lag if we keep adding too much stuff to it. So the things we have to add to it now have to be simple.

development_findings.summary: The game crashes on real hardware and in accurate emulators like Ares due to an excess of collision triangles in the level, a technical limitation of the N64 engine.
development_findings.quote: We have too many collision triangles if that's happening.

development_findings.summary: After receiving negative feedback on a beta test for removing the ability to change direction during a dive, Kaze implemented a compromise: players can change direction but lose speed, which has been better received.
development_findings.quote: People are like twice as mad if you take it away than if they had never had it.

development_findings.summary: When creating a new low-poly CRT model based on a detailed reference, Kaze has to make artistic and technical compromises, simplifying the geometry and planning to use textures to create details like a metallic trim.
development_findings.quote: I think we can't go for 100% accuracy here. I think something like this is what we need to go for. And then we can do the silver line here with the texture.

development_findings.summary: Kaze explains that many ROM hackers prioritize creating a fun, playable game for emulators over the difficult and time-consuming task of ensuring full N64 hardware compatibility.
development_findings.quote: The truth is, most people that make Mario 64X don't care about the N64 that much. They care about making games that people can play. So for them, there's little reason to actually target, like go through all the work to make it N64 compatible.

development_findings.summary: The hub world will be a fully explorable Yoshi's Island with a flute-based musical theme, and Kaze plans for it to contain more secrets than the original Mario 64.
development_findings.quote: The hub will be Yoshi's Island, and it's going to be all flute-themed to fit the Yoshi aesthetic.

context_findings.summary: Kaze believes the hub world is the most critical part of a game like this, as it ties everything together. He is saving it for last to ensure it's perfected based on the designs of all the other levels.
context_findings.quote: The hub world is I think the only reason Mario 64 was famous, popular. If Mario 64 hadn't had a hub world, I don't think anyone would have liked the game.

context_findings.summary: Kaze is considering a dual release strategy: a free N64 ROM hack with Mario, and a commercial version on Steam using static recompilation, with all Nintendo IP (assets, character, code) removed and replaced.
context_findings.quote: Obviously, I would replace all Nintendo assets and would kick out the last bit of Nintendo code as well. I'm not just going to release a Mario game on Steam. That would literally be insanity.

context_findings.summary: Kaze reflects on the socio-economic differences between Germany and Canada, stating that German taxes and social systems would make his current work financially unviable there, contrasting with his life in Canada.
context_findings.quote: If I lived in Germany and I was only ROM hacking, I would make more money if I just did ROM hack. Like, it would be cheaper for me to live in Germany if I didn't work than if I did work.

context_findings.summary: Kaze describes his intense, self-imposed isolation during university to focus entirely on work, acknowledging the negative impact it had on his mental health.
context_findings.quote: I was in university for four years. And I, on purpose, just didn't go out to meet people. Because I wanted to spend all my time working. That is not good for your mental health. And I don't recommend anyone does that.

context_findings.summary: Kaze is hesitant to use crowdfunding platforms like Kickstarter due to a lack of understanding and fear of complex sales tax laws.
context_findings.quote: I'm scared of using Kickstarter and because of sales tax loss. I don't understand how they work with Kickstarter and I'm kind of scared of getting completely fucked.

context_findings.summary: Kaze expresses concern about collaborating with volunteer artists who may not understand the technical constraints of N64 development, leading to him spending more time teaching than is saved by their contribution.

biobak.summary: Kaze and Biobak collaborated on a boss concept ('Octoyoshi'). Biobak provided critical feedback that the initial idea was too cryptic for players.
biobak.quote: I was talking to Biobak about the Yoshi boss idea that we had and maybe wanted to make into the game and I agree with what he said about it being maybe a little cryptic.

biobak.summary: Biobak proposed alternative boss mechanics, suggesting the boss attacks from black holes with its face and tentacles and that the player has to jump into its mouth to destroy tumors inside.
biobak.quote: Biobak was thinking something like this. He gets sent kind of far away. Yeah, we were thinking maybe he like attacks out of black holes with his face and his tentacles mostly.

biobak.summary: Biobak is currently reworking the art and design for Course 2.

zeina.summary: Zeina, Kaze's wife, is an animator on the team and created drawings for the Shy Guy NPCs that will populate the levels.

key_stories.title: The Gramophone Staircase
key_stories.summary: While designing a path in Course 15, Kaze needed a way for the player to gain height. After dismissing a boring antenna idea, he conceived of a giant gramophone and, in a moment of creative inspiration, decided to build a climbable piano-key staircase into its side, solving the design problem with a memorable set piece.
key_stories.challenge: A platforming section in Course 15 needed a vertical element to allow the player to ascend, but the initial idea was uninspired.
key_stories.process: Kaze first considered a climbable antenna but disliked the idea. He then brainstormed alternatives, leading to the idea of a giant gramophone. To make it climbable, he came up with the concept of building stairs directly into its side.
key_stories.outcome: The idea was immediately adopted, with Kaze modeling a staircase built into a gramophone using piano keys, creating a unique, thematically appropriate, and visually interesting platforming element.
key_stories.key_quote: Wait, I kind of love that idea. That's just the type of schizophrenic thinking you need to be in a game.

key_stories.title: Debugging the Collision Crash
key_stories.summary: While trying to test Course 15's performance on a real N64, the game repeatedly crashed. Kaze systematically debugged the issue using the Ares emulator, concluding that the level's geometric complexity exceeded the engine's limit for collision surfaces. This technical barrier halted his progress on console testing for the day.
key_stories.challenge: The game crashes on real hardware when loading a complex part of Course 15, preventing performance testing.
key_stories.process: Kaze first experienced the crash on his N64. To debug faster, he replicated it on the cycle-accurate emulator, Ares. He then hypothesized the cause was too many collision triangles and confirmed it by disabling collision on objects until the level loaded successfully.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze confirmed the issue was too many collision surfaces for the N64 engine to handle. The immediate problem prevented him from testing performance on console during the stream, forcing him to shelve the task and plan to reduce collision complexity later.
key_stories.key_quote: We just have too many surface nodes, that makes sense. Fair enough that we get a crash there.

key_stories.title: Creating the Retro CRT
key_stories.summary: Kaze decided to create the final asset for the in-game CRT monitors. He used a real-world retrofuturistic TV as a reference, modeled a low-poly version, and began tackling the difficult challenge of creating a convincing shiny gold material using N64-compatible texturing tricks.
key_stories.challenge: The placeholder CRT monitors in the game needed to be replaced with a final, retro-futuristic model that would work within N64 limitations.
key_stories.process: Kaze found a reference image of a 1950s Philco Predicta television. He modeled a low-polygon version in Blender, making compromises on detail to save triangles. He then began the complex process of UV mapping and texturing, experimenting with a two-layer texture approach to simulate a reflective gold surface.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze created a low-poly model that captured the essence of the reference image. He devised a technical plan to create a shiny, metallic effect using a combination of a color texture and a moving, semi-transparent 'shine' texture on top, though he ended the stream before fully implementing it.
key_stories.key_quote: Doing that. This should be a random bug. I think this is a vendor market. I don't think it actually does that. Or actually. Okay. All right, there we go. This is the concept.
